comment: I was at the tasting the day it was released. It is a  good Rye Whiskey but not near $125 a bottle good.

Smells young and sweet, but balanced. On the palate, hard to believe this is 2 years old. Sweet, baking spices, bitter chocolate, some cherry, decent finish. You feel the proof but it still goes down smooth. Maybe hard to justify the price tag, but definitely makes you look forward to future offerings. 11/26/17
Absolutely delicious and complex, totally comfortable paying retail around $100.
Thoroughly impressed with Peerless Rye Whiskey. Attention to detail and flavor profile are truly exquisite. A+
Everyone will surely complain about the $120-ish price tag, but I love this. Just the right amount of proof and flavor and spice.
Very good, impressed with depth of flavor for 2 years old. Good kick of spice late with alcohol a little hot after but evens out with chocolate cherry undertones into finish.

Compliments on the bottle design to Carson Taylor and the gang. 
Thoughts: 
Like Willett Rye on steroids, it viscous, and has the same green tea nose- with similar, but bigger and deeper sugary notes in the body. Worth the price. Very very good for 2 years.
Sweet, smooth and heat comes late. VG

I have tasted my fair share of ryes, this is certainly one of the top ones on my list (but maybe not the best). 
Rye spices, caramel and cinnamon. Palate has more spicyness, nutmeg and cloves and licorice. A very long-lasting finish with more caramel and toffee and some  pepper, oak, and, of course, spice. Add a drop of water and the spiciness comes forward and then yields to the rich sweetness noted above. Fantastic rye all around. Can't wait to see what their bourbon will be like next year!

Tasted at the distillery in November 2017 during a bourbon trail Long weekend. I could not believe this was a 2 year old rye whiskey. Great whiskey. The best whiskey we had all weekend. It is pricey for sure. Single barrel store pick I found was actually even better than barrel proof from the distillery.

$110+ for a two year rye from an untested distillery. So it has come to this.

Note: 5/11 current notes for this come from accounts that have fewer than 5 notes and rate this as exceptional--one account gave WLW four stars and this five...
Very Smooth, good spearmint finish. Light body and finish.

Has got to be in the top 3 ryes I've ever had. Perfectly balanced, there's a slight medicinal on the nose followed with some cedar and spice, brown sugar and cinnamon. Tasting gives way to lots of intricate flavors all perfectly balanced. Very smooth sweet vanilla "creme brulee" alongside the spicy rye and pepper notes. Didn't pick up too too much oak in this one, but it was there. Good mouthfeel too from what I can remember. Great, great bottle. If you can find it sub $100 it's worth it. Even over, I'd consider it anyday. Looking forward to their other future offerings.

3.75-4.0
Tasting bar @ Lukas Wine & Spirits.

Verdict: Bar
Really enjoyed this, but $110 for a 2 year old rye?!

A fantastic (if not the best) rye whiskey. Notes of black pepper blend with the vanilla nicely to create a sweet and smooth finish. The question is though, is it worth the much higher price point than other ryes that may not be as good, but are still great for half the price? I have a hard time saying yes... but their bottle does look great on a shelf.
Fantastic and full bodied! The taste exceeds the packaging and that says a lot for this rye. Price point a bit high but a top pour for sure.

Maybe the best rye i’ve had.  Its special when compared to pilesville.  Its kinda like sazerac rye not in flavor profile but in being unique.  Sweet and smooth with a bit of spice at the end.  Very faint alcohol smell and taste.  Def taste better than its age(i tried a 3 yr store pick btw).  But that price tag makes my heart ache though.  Wished it was $50
Nice bite, great finish. Loved visiting distillery

Fool me once shame on you.......

Well well Well, the controversial 2 year expensive juice. I have to say this is pretty good, however, the price should deter any potential buyers. It’s just not worth the buck-and-a-quarter price because there are PLENTY of other very good buys much cheaper. If it were in the $60 range I would say get a bottle. Regardless, I don’t regret spending what I did, I just won’t do it again. 3.2/5
Barrel proof....yet very nice nose & pallet! So smooth....very drinkable!
Look this is smooth and good, but it has no depth. Its super smooth, but just no bang, no pop, no nothing. Just smooth whiskey. Not special, not worth the $109 price tag

Improvement over the first tasting after this bottle was opened about six weeks. 

Nose: vanilla spice and yes corn. Hints of butterscotch and less of the funk from before, hints of biscuits and tea

Palate: quite rich and sweet, but hot on the mid palate, nutmeg, heavy spice on the end 

 Finish: rye kicks it up a notch along with the proof for significant warmth, still rich and bright

The nose is fantastic now but toward the finish it gets a bit muddled. Will check in with it later.

Their single barrel known as "Apple Crisp" and "Latte". Both were extremely smooth for rye. The latte had a big nose of chocolate and coffee. The apple crisp has a prominent nose of cinnamon and spice with some vanilla.

getting leather on the nose. it's like a leather shoe stuffed with peanuts. the more it sits, the sweeter the the nose. then it's like leather shoe stuffed with peanuts but like the owner stepped on some bubble gum. 
pallate is just leather shoes though.

I want to hate this bottle. Aged 2 years and asking $100 a bottle, thats just stupid. All that said, it is an incredibly smooth sipper. Bravo to the distillery. I don’t think its worth $100, but as a gift, the gift receiver will not be disappointed.
Dilute for best, banana nut bread aftertaste

I approached this whiskey with a heavy dose of skepticism given the juxtaposition of its high cost and low (2 year) age statement. That being said, I was pleasantly surprised and now count myself a Peerless convert. With a few minutes in the glass, the nose unfolds from an initial hit of ethanol into rich vanilla, dried apricots, orange oil, roasted peanuts, toffee, a light note of mint, and balanced with a bit of sweet coffee. The palate is immediately sweet and rich with vanilla, graham crackers, toasted sugars, allspice, a light grassy-herbal note, a very light caramel, honey roasted peanuts, and a very pleasant malty note, before transitioning to a warm, slightly herbal, vanilla-laden exhale. Further sips bring out more rich sweetness with a stronger note of dried apricots, powdered sugar, and an extremely pleasant bit of spice and fiery burn. Not a super complex whiskey, but an extremely pleasant and all around impressive offering from Peerless. I look forward to continuing to try their rye as it ages.
Spicy flavor bomb! Buy it, you won’t regret! My favorite rye!
Spicy and bold nose. Starts sweet, hint of vanilla, oak and slightly sweet. Finishes spicy.

This one was interesting. Very forward with the notes. Though as I nosed and tasted later in, I could pick out more.
I let this one breath for about 10mins or so before I took a sip. And I will say, when I went for a 2nd pour, I couldn’t taste as much as I could with the pour that had breathed for a bit.

The nose is a little vanilla, mint, green apple
The palate is a little sweet, and slight leather, that leads to a spicyness that you expect from a rye. A good amount of spice.
The finish has the spices burn on the back of the throat.
It’s a good whiskey that is hard to believe it’s only two years old. Letting it breathe is the key I think. Adding a little water diluted it too much.

Got the 200mL bottle before I splurged in the big boy. We’ll have to see how the rest of the bottle goes before I decide to if I think the price is worth it. It’s good and somewhat unique though.
Nice amount of spice, lots of brown sugar, maple notes, smooth.

Smooth and rich with just enough classic rye spice.  It's a nice sipper, but not as good as the price would have you believe.  Glad I found a 200ml sample size to try for $30, would have been disappointed to spend $109 on a whole bottle of this.
Surprisingly good for a 2 year rye!
Not a lot on the nose to me but a very funky cool rye flavor... I get like a buttered rye toast.
Pretty solid taste but a tad bland from what I expected
It smells good, hint of spice and vanilla but when I tasted it neat, the spice was too overpowering for my palate.  It would be good in a cocktail such as an old fashioned though.

Yeah FOMO got the best of me, so I forked out $24 ($29 minus $5 reward cert) at TW to try this 2 yr old Rye (200 ml bottle). Is it possible that a Rye that young could live up to it's $125 price tag? Would the 107 entry proof, sweet mash process and micro batch really make up for it's youth... Let's dive in:

Sampling this rye neat it definitely comes across as hot and young. Ethanol, pine, anise and some herbal funk. Not really something that I enjoy. I quickly make the decision to drop a small ice cube to see if I can tame this and bring out some better notes. That did the trick to a certain extent calming the herbal notes and bringing forth some sweet notes (brown sugar and candy corn). Finish lingers and is filled with more of an alcohol burn. In short this one falls way short of a full bottle purchase and to be honest I don't know that it's worth $24 to try it. Just not my profile. 

Cheers all and Happy Halloween!

This is amazingly good for a two year rye. Very sweet on the front with that rye on the back. Almost reminds me of a toasted finish Michters or a Willet family estate rye. Moderate to long finish. I would buy even at 100 bucks.

very unique nose and taste.  the most pure rye nose and flavor I've ever had.  bright rye on first taste but finished with fresh rye bread which was delightful.  small glimpse of spearmint but it wasn't overtaking the rye bread.  great rye but not sure I would pay $100 to have in my collection.  For 60 or less,  absolutely!
Good so far, actually this is the small batch, but the app kept crashing as I tried to submit it
Awesome but the price point is way off.
Fine, but not worth the cost

108.8 proof
54.4 %
151021102
Nose: sour cream notes....a little musty. Not much else and not approachable.  

Palate: much better than the nose, that’s for sure. Sweet grass, oak, spices. A little briny. 

Finish: pretty fast considering this is barrel strength 

Will have to come back to this. Something funky going on here.
Nose is vanilla and brown sugar, oak. Palate obviously heavy rye, strong bite-but nice, dry and enjoyable. Nice oak presence
Best Rye I’ve had in a while

Nose: Big fruity notes of cherry and peach subside into a vanilla/cinnamon cream.  Reminds be of a cherry or peach cream cheese danish!  Underneath that breakfast pastry base is a a sour oak and rye note that is hard to identify - kind of like wet wood.

Palate: Sweet and oily on the tongue.  Big bursts of cinnamon, clove, and vanilla cream.  There is a surprising large wood influence for such a young whiskey.  There's just the slightest hint of that classic rye herbal note that I usually find offputting, but it's dialed back enough for me to really enjoy this. 

Finish:  Rather lengthy and sweet.  The dominating notes are of vanilla and caramel.  A little corn dust and leather creep in toward the end along with an unmistakable pecan flavor.

Conclusion:  I've found another rye I actually enjoy!  I like the spicy breakfast pastry flavors it reminds of quite a bit.  It's a bit pricy for the liquid inside, but I'd buy it if I found a deal.

Read a bunch of notes while tasting, and wondered if I was tasting the same whiskey. I get sweet corn, rye bread, heat, hint of mint, and pine on the nose. A sip delivers sweet spices to the front of the tongue, transitioning to grainy corn and rye notes, fading to anise and spearmint. A healthy dose of heat throughout, unfortunately it tends to amplify the graininess on the mid palate.

Honestly, $100 for a rye pour that fails to deliver a bonafide rye punch, lacks the complexity of a more mature product, and really fails to differentiate itself from a sea of average $20-$35 ryes on the market is laughable to me. Grateful that I got this as a sample, and did not have to spend the coin to be this disappointed. Maybe when this is an 8-9 year product it MIGHT be worth the asking price.

Until then, it’s a hard pass for me. I’ll gladly buy 2 bottles of Pikesville, or any number of lower priced MGPs, or even step up to a Kentucky Owl.
Not a big fan of mint so this one is tough. Definitely has those mint tones. Still isn't bad. Might have to try again outside a flight to verify.
Solid rye flavor. Will be great in old fashioneds.
I love the heat with peerless. I’m finishing up my bottle and will miss it from my stash. Heat lasts throughout. Smoke upfront and I get a late rush of licorice.
Spicy rye flavor with a full mouth feel and vanilla notes. Smooth, almost vanishing, finish.
Spicy with hints of vanilla. Just like my older brother who bought me this bottle.
I can’t get past the astringent oak as the dominant flavor. Nice but not tops.

Sweet and spicy on the nose. Feels like a mix of wintergreen and spearmint gum. Maybe orange zest. Feels fresh.Spice comes through. Spicy front to back in the mouth with a backing of caramel, vanilla, and sugar that keeps the spice mellow. Very little kick despite 108 proof. Taste lingers after swallow. Smooth and easy to drink but continually brings me back for new flavors, particularly on the nose. Plus, the bottling is gorgeous. I got mine at a steal, $55/bottle for a barrel select. I tasted while there and elected to get 2 bottles. Not sure I’d pay asking for it, but for what I paid, it’d be an instant buy.
Slightly sweet, hot but not too hot, very solid
Spicy and hot at beginning but smooths our and a lingering sweetness. Long finish
